active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the trade-offs between user privacy (e.g., location and health data in fitness trackers) and security requirements for first responders using wearables. Reference NISTIR 8196 threat models and justify positions with real-world examples from breaches like Fitbit data leaks.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Digital Forensics for IoT Wearables. Topic: Wearable Device Analysis (Smartwatches, Fitness Trackers). Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > 002_Incident Response And Forensics > Digital Forensics > 012_Specialized Forensics Domains > IoT Forensics > Wearable Device Analysis. Incorporate these elements: - Learning Objectives: [REMEMBER: Define key terms... ] (use all 6, balance coverage across 20-30 flashcards). - Scaffolding: Generate flashcards progressively: 30% Layer 1 (Foundation), 25% Layer 2 (Components), 25% Layer 3 (Implementation), 20% Layer 4 (Integration). Tag each with layer. - Active Learning: Infuse prompts tying to discussion/peer teaching/problem-solving (e.g., 'Apply in scenario...'). - Prior Knowledge: Link to digital forensics basics, mobile IR. - Best Practices: NISTIR 8196 (threat models, security objectives for wearables in public safety), NISTIR 8235 (procurement, risk assessments, forensic methods like imaging/chain of custody). Sources: NISTIR 8196 (https://doi.org/10.6028/NIST.IR.8196), NISTIR 8235 (https://doi.org/10.6028/NIST.IR.8235). Generate 50 high-quality flashcards following this schema: Front: [Bloom's level] [Layer] Question (MCQ/cloze/short answer). Back: - Answer: ... - Explanation: ... (pedagogical, distractor rationale, NIST tie-in). - Reference: ... - Active Tie-in: ... Vary types: 40% MCQ (3 distractors per protocol: misconception, related error, partial truth), 30% cloze, 20% short answer, 10% scenario. Ensure university-level rigor, active recall, spaced repetition optimization. Output as numbered JSON array: [{'front': '...', 'back': {'answer': '...', 'explanation': '...', 'reference': '...', 'active_tie_in': '...'}}, ...].
